answers.answer: Hi,The treatment with aspirin and clopidogrel (Plavix) won’t be a guarantee that you wouldn’t need another coronary procedure, especially in the presence of Diabetes. Inquire from your doctor if you are at risk for a heredity problem with lipids – as you may require more intensive treatment to control cholesterol.While there is a rich blood supply for the penis indeed it is entirely possible that a reaction to cold is what you say. The arteries generally carry warmer blood and subserve the function of maintaining body temperature. Hence as arteries reach the tips (like the tips of the fingers) the temperature starts dropping and so the symptom emerges.The best protection is to keep yourself warm.It is also possible that if you are sedentary you are forming plaques that may be floating in the circulation, and these may lodge permanently in small vessels. If the symptom you described is prolonged or if there is pain, it may be best to see a doctor right away.

question: It started a couple years ago:  my right foot, especially the toes, would get cold to the point of having a painful burning sensation in it.  That would usually happen while I would be relaxed, as in being a couch potato.  This past winter the same thing started with the head of my penis.  Had to resort to putting a pad inside my briefs to keep it warm and pain free.I have CAD (7 coronary stents) and PAD (2 stents in left subclavian for SSS).  Got these one at a time during the past 7 years.  Add in Type II diabetes, high blood pressure and lipids.  About 2 months ago I had an ABI: left side 1.0, right side 0.87.  I get buttock and thigh pains while walking.  Had a urologist check things out last month.  No infection, no STD, PSA is ok but I do have some ED.  The coldness and pain disappear whenever I can get an erection but it doesn't last long.I assume that I have a blood circulation problem with my penis.  The urologist assured me that there are lots of arteries supplying blood to the penis, and I don't have anything to worry about.  However, considering the experience I've gained over the past few years, that doesn't reassure me. I'm already taking a daily handful of pills including Plavix and aspirin so according to the advertising, plaque should not be a problem.  But I've been taking them since 2000 and still got stents.What I would like to know:  Is this going to be a static but cronic problem?  Can it be fixed?  What are the potential problems I might have in the future and can those be avoided?
title: Head of penis gets cold, turns blue
